author: frozenfire.eth
content:
I'm thinking through how one would standardize efficient consumable recipient addresses for use in ZK account abstraction.

In my conception of this, one would provide a sender a predictable address, which forms a commitment for a contract whose init code acts as nothing more than a proof verifier that sends its balance to a specified address when a valid proof is provided.

So a recipient would take the standard init code for this contract, and would hash it with other predictable CREATE(/2) parameters in order to generate the address which such a contract *would* be deployed to, but doesn't deploy it.

They provide that address to a sender, who sends ETH/tokens to the uninitialized address. The recipient can then later execute (or have a third party execute) the CREATE op + consume call.

author: frozenfire.eth
content: The purpose of this would be to enable pooled contract wallets to have non-identifying recipient addresses, without requiring senders to conform to a non-standard/dynamic recipient address specification - maintaining backwards compatibility.

content: Working on a proof of concept for this: https://github.com/TheFrozenFire/slurp
